request.description:
# Get recent Replies

Replies (or Comments) to a post are contained in a separate database collection. However, this endpoint has the ability to present the most recent 3 comments by specifying the `replies` query field.

The replies field is structured like so:

```
replies {
   id,
   count,
   recent {
        id,
        author {
          id,
          username,
          account_type,
          profile_photo_url
        }, 
        message,
        post,
        children,
        attachments { ... },
        likes,
        dislikes,
        parent_id,
        reply_type
   }
}
```

The `replies` query field has a `recent` sub-field, which returns an array of the most recent 3 comments.

The `recent` sub-field follows the `Reply` Schema type. The schema looks like this on the backend:

```
 type Reply {
        id: String,
        author: Author, 
        message: String,
        post: String,
        children: [String],
        attachments: [Attachment],
        likes: [String],
        dislikes: [String],
        parent_id: String,
        reply_type: String
    }
```

Let's break down some of the more confusing fields of `Reply`: `post`, `children`, `parent_id` and `reply_type` as well as how they are used in the Icered api.

* `post` - This is the original post, you'll see this in all "Replies", no matter how deep you go into a thread.

* `children` - This is an array of `replyID`s. If a reply is made to another reply, it shows up here as an ID. Generally, this should only be used to count the size of the children. We don't show the actual content here. Its best to use the `getPostRepliesById` query for this.

* `parent_id` - If the `parent_id` isn't `0`, that means it is a reply to another reply (comment). It tells you what the parent comment is. If it is `0`, then that means it is a top-level comment, directly to the post itself.

* `reply_type` - This will almost always be a reply_type of `post`. Simply because in the future, we may want to add things like gifs and stickers, which will have their own `reply_type`. This should let the user interface know how to style the reply.

response.name: Get All Forums

graphql.query:
query {
    getPosts(
        start_at: 0,
        interest: "any",
        search: "",
        country_code: 1,
        sort: "desc",
        limit: 10,
        exclude: [
            "bots"
        ]
    ) {
        id,
        author {
            id,
            name,
            name_type,
            account_type,
            profile_photo_url
        },
        title,
        body,
        type,
        attachments {
            author {
                id,
                name,
                name_type,
                profile_photo_url
            },
            type,
            data
        },
        likes,
        dislikes,
        shares,
        interest,
        country_code,
        replies_count,
        createdAt,
        updatedAt
    }
}

        exclude: [
            "bots"
        ]
    ) {
        id,
        author {
            id,
            name,
            name_type,
            profile_photo_url
        },
        title,
        body,
        type,
        attachments {
            author {
                id,
                name,
                name_type,
                profile_photo_url
            },
            type,
            data
        },
        likes,
        dislikes,
        shares,
        interest,
        country_code,

        interests,
        topics
    }
}
